sections.title: Braidings and quantizations of Maxwell's equations
sections.abstract:
This paper extends the grading and the symmetry of the $\mathbb{Z}$-graded superalgebras of differential operators $D^*(A)$ and differential forms $\wedge^*(A)$ on an associative algebra $A$.

We consider the associative algebra $A=\mathbb{C}[x_1,\dots,x_n]$ as graded by  $\mathbb{Z}^{n}$ and consider the algebras $D^*(A)$ and $\wedge^*(A)$ within the tensor category of  $\mathbb{Z}^{n+1}$-graded modules. Any braiding/symmetry and any categorical quantization are completely described in terms of this grading.

We explore the quantizations of these algebras with corresponding quantized multiplications. We further describe  the braided and quantized braided structures of the algebras' derivations,  curvatures,  differential forms,  inner derivations and exterior derivations.

We apply these results to the associative algebra $A=\mathbb{C}[x, y, z, t]$ and investigate and compare the quantizations of the electromagnetic 2-form and the Maxwell's equations expressed in terms of differential forms in two settings: in the tensor categories of $\mathbb{Z}^{4}$-graded and $\mathbb{Z}^{5}$-graded modules.
sections.author: H.\,Huru
sections.keywords: Braidings, Categorical Quantizations, Polynomial Algebra, Differential Algebras, Electromagnetic 2-form, Maxwells equations
sections.introduction:
Super and graded theories in a differential setting  where explored by Kersten and Krasil'shcik in \cite{KrasilKersten} for associative $\mathbb{Z}^n$-graded algebras symmetric with respect to the symmetry $ab=(-1)^{|a|\cdot |b|} ba$, where $|a|\cdot |b|$ is the scalar product of the gradings $|a|,|b|,\in\mathbb{Z}^n$ of homogeneous elements $a$ and $b$.
We will in this paper explore this for all possible symmetries of the category of $\mathbb{Z}^n$-graded modules.

Let $A$ be an associative algebra over $\mathbb{C}$.
The algebras $D^*(A)$ and $\wedge^*(A)$ of skew-symmetric polyderivations and differential forms are graded by $\mathbb{Z}$ and are with respect to the wedge product superalgebras, see \cite{KrasilKersten}. If $A$ is an algebra graded by an abelian group $G$, then the algebras $D^*(A)$ and $\wedge^*(A)$ are graded by $G\times \mathbb{Z}$. We consider $G=\mathbb{Z}^{n}$.

We investigate monoidal \cite{maclane}, or quasitensor \cite{CP}, categories equipped with a braiding $\sigma=\sigma_{X,Y}:X\otimes Y\to Y\otimes X$, where $X,Y$ are objects of the category considered.
If $\sigma_{X,Y}=\sigma_{Y,X}$ then $\sigma$ is a symmetry. We confine ourselves to symmetries and tensor categories only.
A symmetry in the tensor category of $\mathbb{Z}^{n+1}$-graded modules is completely described by the grading, see e.g. \cite{h3,ABC}.

A categorical quantization $q$ in a quasitensor category is a natural isomorphism
$q=q_{X,Y}:X\otimes Y \to X \otimes Y$
for objects $X$ and $Y$ that satisfies the Lychagin coherence condition, see \cite{ABC}.
A categorical quantization in the quasitensor category of $\mathbb{Z}^{n+1}$-graded modules
is completely described in terms of the grading, see \cite{h3,lq}.

Our main example of a $\mathbb{Z}^{n}$-graded algebra is the polynomial algebra $A=\mathbb{C}[x_1,\dots,x_n]$. We quantize, or deform, this algebra, and in connection with this derivations $W$, differential forms $\lambda$, connections $\nabla_\lambda$, curvatures $K_{\nabla_\lambda}$, inner derivations $i_W$ and exterior derivations $d(\lambda)$.
Moreover, we quantize the $\mathbb{Z}^{n+1}$-graded (super)algebras $D^*(A)$ and $\wedge^*(A)$ within this framework.

Finally we investigate the electromagnetic 2-form $F$ and the Maxwell's equations. We describe their quantizations in the two settings when the polynomial algebra $\mathbb{C}[t,x,y,z]$ is quantized in the tensor category of $\mathbb{Z}^{4}$-graded modules, and when $D^*(\mathbb{C}[t,x,y,z])$ and $\wedge^*(\mathbb{C}[t,x,y,z])$ are quantized in the tensor category of $\mathbb{Z}^{5}$-graded modules. This is done by quantizations of curvatures and exterior algebras in these categories as $F=K_{\nabla_\lambda}$ and $F=d(\lambda)$ respectively, for a given 1-form $\lambda$ and a given symmetry.
main_part:
As mentioned we shall distinguish between $\mathbb{Z}^{n}$-grading and $\mathbb{Z}^{n+1}$-grading. To do this denote quantizations of the respective tensor categories $M_{\mathbb{C}}(\mathbb{Z}^{n})$ and $M_{\mathbb{C}}(\mathbb{Z}^{n+1})$ by $q$ and $\bar q$, and similarly denote symmetries respectively by $\sigma$ and $\bar \sigma$. When an element $x$ is considered as $\mathbb{Z}^{n}$-graded the grading is denoted by $|x|$, and when it is considered as $\mathbb{Z}^{(n+1)}$-graded the grading is denoted by $|\bar x|$.

We consider the algebra $\wedge^1(A)$ of 1-forms
of the algebra $A=\mathbb{C}[x_1,\dots,x_n]$ and the exterior algebra
\begin{align}\label{altern1}
\wedge^{\cdot}(A)=\sum_{r=0}^\infty\wedge^r(A)
\end{align}
where the $r$-forms are $\wedge^r(A)=\wedge^r(\wedge^1(A))$.
Moreover, we consider the dual of derivations/first order differential operators of $A$\begin{align*}
\wedge^1(A_\chi)^*=Hom_{\mathbb{C}}(\wedge^1(A_\chi),A)=D^1(A_{-\chi}),
\quad \chi\in\mathbb{Z}^{n},
\end{align*}\begin{align}\label{altern}
\wedge^{\cdot}(A)^*=D^{\cdot}(A)=\sum_{r=0}^\infty\wedge^r(A)^*.
\end{align}
For more details see \cite{krasil}. The algebras $\wedge^{\cdot}(A)$
and $D^{\cdot}(A)$ are graded by $\mathbb{Z}^{n+1}$, with the
following homogeneous elements
\begin{itemize}
\item $f=x_1^{i_1}\dots x_n^{i_n}\in A=\mathbb{C}[x_1,\dots,x_n]$ with the grading ${|\bar f|
%=(|f|,0)
=\left(\begin{array}{c}
i_1\\
\vdots\\
i_n\\
0
\end{array}\right)}\in \mathbb{Z}^{n+1};$
\item  $F=f_idx_i\in\wedge^1(A)$ for homogeneous $f_i\in A$ with the grading  $|\bar F|
=|f_i| + 1_{n+1}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n+1}$;
\item $F=F_1\wedge \cdots \wedge F_r\in\wedge^r(A)$ for homogeneous $F_i\in\wedge^1(A),i=1,\dots,r$ with the grading  $|\bar F|=|\bar F_1|+\cdots +|\bar
F_r|\in\mathbb{Z}^{n+1}$;
\item $W=f_i\partial_i\in D^1(A)$ for homogeneous $f_i\in A$ with grading $|\bar W|
=-|f_i|- 1_{n+1}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n+1}$;
\item $W=W_1\wedge\cdots\wedge W_r \in D^r(A)$ for homogeneous $W_i\in D^1(A),i=1,\dots,r$ with grading $|\bar W|=|\bar W_1|+\cdots+|\bar W_r|
\in\mathbb{Z}^{n+1}$.
\end{itemize}
Let $\bar\sigma$ be a symmetry of $M_{\mathbb{C}}(\mathbb{Z}^{n+1})$. The \textit{$\bar\sigma$-symmetric wedge product}$\wedge_{\bar\sigma}$ on the algebra $A$ has the property
%\begin{align*}$a\wedge_{\bar\sigma} b=\bar\sigma(|a|,|b|)b\wedge_{\bar\sigma} a
$%\end{align*}
  for two homogeneous elements $a,b\in A$.
With this wedge product the exterior algebra and the algebra of
differential operators become $\bar\sigma$-commutative algebras,
with respect to the symmetry $\bar\sigma$. We denote these by
$\wedge_{\bar\sigma}^{\cdot}(A)$ and
$D_{\bar\sigma}^{\cdot}(A)=\wedge_{\bar\sigma}^{\cdot}(A)^*$. These
$\bar\sigma$-symmetric algebras are constructed from
(\ref{altern1}), (\ref{altern}) that originally have the symmetry
$\tau$ of (\ref{sdecomp}) and have the wedge product $ a\wedge
b=(-1)^{|a|_{\mathbb{Z}}|b|_{\mathbb{Z}}}b\wedge a $, with
$|a|_{\mathbb{Z}},|b|_{\mathbb{Z}}\in\mathbb{Z}$. The symmetry
$\tau$ may be combined with any other symmetry  $\sigma$ as in
(\ref{sdecomp}), belonging to the "underlying" tensor category of
$\mathbb{Z}^n$-graded modules $M_{\mathbb{C}}(\mathbb{Z}^{n})$,
giving the wedge product
%\begin{align*}$a\wedge_\sigma
b=(-1)^{|a|_{\mathbb{Z}}|b|_{\mathbb{Z}}}\sigma(|a|,|b|)b\wedge_\sigma
a $% \end{align*}
   with $|a|,|b|\in\mathbb{Z}^n$. These are quantized
by $\gamma$ of (\ref{sdecomp}) and after quantization we get the
"full" symmetry $\bar\sigma$ of (\ref{sdecomp}). See \cite{h4} for
details.

Define a \textit{$\bar\sigma$-symmetric pairing} of two elements $\lambda=\lambda_1\wedge_{\bar\sigma} \cdots\wedge_{\bar\sigma}\lambda_r\in\wedge^r_{\bar\sigma}(A), W=W_1\wedge_{\bar\sigma} \cdots\wedge_{\bar\sigma}W_r\in D^r_{\bar\sigma}(A)$ as follows

\begin{align}
\langle W,\lambda\rangle_{\bar \sigma}
&=\bar\sigma(|\bar W_1|,|\bar W_2| + \dots |\bar W_{r}|)
\sum_{i=1}^r \bar\sigma(|\bar W_1|,|\bar \lambda_1|+\cdots +|\bar \lambda_{i-1}|)\cdot \notag\\
&\cdot \langle W_1,\lambda_i\rangle
\langle W_2\wedge_{\bar\sigma}\dots\wedge_{\bar\sigma} W_{r}, \lambda_1\wedge_{\bar\sigma} \cdots\wedge_{\bar\sigma} \hat\lambda_i\wedge_{\bar\sigma} \cdots\wedge_{\bar\sigma}\lambda_r\rangle_{\bar\sigma}
\end{align}
where $ \langle W_1,\lambda_i\rangle $ is defined in
(\ref{pairing1}). This satisfies $ \langle W,\lambda
\wedge_{\bar\sigma} \theta \rangle_{\bar \sigma} = \langle W,\lambda
\rangle_{\bar \sigma} + \bar\sigma(|\bar W|,|\bar\lambda|) \langle
W,  \theta \rangle_{\bar \sigma} $, for $\lambda \wedge_{\bar\sigma}
\theta\in\wedge^r_{\bar\sigma}(A),W\in D^r_{\bar\sigma}(A)$. Clearly
if $W\in D^1_{\bar\sigma} (A)$ and $\lambda\in \wedge^1_{\bar\sigma}
(A)$, then $ \langle W,\lambda\rangle_{\bar \sigma}=\langle
W,\lambda\rangle=\lambda_W $.

\subsection{$\bar\sigma$-symmetric exterior and inner derivatives}
The \textit{$\bar\sigma$-symmetric de Rham differential}, or $ \bar\sigma $-exterior derivative,
%\begin{align*}$d^{\bar\sigma}:\wedge_{\bar\sigma}^r(A)\to\wedge_{\bar\sigma}^{r+1}(A)
$%\end{align*}
is defined as follows
\begin{align*}
d^{\bar\sigma}\lambda(W_0,\dots,W_{r})=&
\sum_{i=0}^{r}\bar \sigma(|\bar W_0|+\cdots+|\bar W_{i-1}|,|\bar W_i|)W_i(\langle W_0\wedge_{\bar\sigma} \dots\wedge_{\bar\sigma} \hat W_i\wedge_{\bar\sigma}\dots\wedge_{\bar\sigma}W_{r},\lambda\rangle_{\bar\sigma})
\\
-&
\sum_{i<j}\bar \sigma(|\bar W_0|+\cdots+|\bar W_{i-1}|,|\bar W_i|)
\bar \sigma(|\bar W_0|+\cdots+|\hat W_i|+\cdots+|\bar W_{j-1}|,|\bar W_j|)
\cdot \\
\cdot &
\langle[W_i,W_j]^{\bar\sigma}\wedge_{\bar\sigma} W_0\wedge_{\bar\sigma} \dots\wedge_{\bar\sigma}\hat W_i\wedge_{\bar\sigma}\dots\wedge_{\bar\sigma}\hat W_j\wedge_{\bar\sigma}\dots\wedge_{\bar\sigma}W_{r},\lambda\rangle_{\bar\sigma}
\end{align*}
for $\lambda\in\wedge^r_{\bar\sigma}(A), W_i\in D^1_{\bar\sigma}(A),i=0,\dots ,r$.

The $ \bar\sigma $-exterior derivative satisfies the $ \bar\sigma $-symmetric Leibniz rule
\begin{align}
d(\lambda\wedge_{\bar\sigma}\theta) =d(\lambda)\wedge_{\bar\sigma}\theta
+\bar\sigma(|\bar d|,|\bar \lambda|)\lambda\wedge_{\bar\sigma}d(\theta)
\end{align}
for $\lambda\in\wedge^r_{\bar\sigma}(A),\theta\in\wedge^s_{\bar\sigma}(A)$. Also,
$
d^2=0
$
is satisfied, and
we have a $ \bar\sigma $-symmetric de Rham complex
\begin{align*}
0\to A\to \wedge^1_{\bar\sigma}(A)\overset{d}{\to} \wedge^2_{\bar\sigma}(A)\overset{d}{\to} \cdots \overset{d}{\to} \wedge^r_{\bar\sigma}(A)\overset{d}{\to} \wedge^{r+1}_{\bar\sigma}(A)\overset{d}{\to} \dots
\end{align*}
Note that in the particular case $r=1$ then $d^{\bar\sigma}\lambda$
becomes
\begin{align*}
d^{\bar\sigma}\lambda(W,U)
&=\bar \sigma(\bar 0,|\bar W|)
W(\lambda_U)
+\bar \sigma(|\bar W|,|\bar U|)
U(\lambda_W)
-\bar \sigma(\bar 0,|\bar W|)
\bar \sigma(\bar 0,|\bar U|)
\lambda_{[W,U]^{\bar\sigma}}\\
&=W(\lambda_U) +\bar \sigma(|\bar W|,|\bar U|) U(\lambda_W)
-\lambda_{[W,U]^{\bar\sigma}}.
\end{align*}\begin{remark}\label{dl}
Remark that for the symmetry
$\bar\sigma=\tau$ of (\ref{sdecomp})
we obtain the classical exterior derivative
\begin{align*}
d\lambda(W_0,\dots,W_{r})
&=\sum_{i=0}^{n} (-1)^{i}W_i(\lambda(W_0,\dots,\hat W_i,\dots,W_{r}))\\
&+\sum_{i<j}(-1)^{i+j}\lambda([W_i,W_j],W_0,\dots,\hat
W_i,\dots,\hat W_j,\dots,W_{r}),
\end{align*}
see \cite{krasil}.
In the case $r=1$ we get
$
d^{}\lambda(W,U)
=W(\lambda_U)-U(\lambda_W)-\lambda_{[W,U]}
$,
which is equal that of remark \ref{remarkcurv}.
\end{remark}
The $\bar\sigma$-symmetric \textit{inner derivative}%\begin{align*}$i_X^{\bar\sigma}: \wedge_{\bar\sigma}^r(A_\chi)\to \wedge_{\bar\sigma}^{r-1}(A_{\chi-|X|})
$%\end{align*}
  is defined
\begin{align*}
i_X^{\bar\sigma}(\lambda)(W)=\langle W, i_X^{\bar\sigma}(\lambda)\rangle=\bar\sigma\left(|\bar W|,|\bar X|\right)\langle X\wedge_{\bar\sigma} W,\lambda\rangle
\end{align*}
for $X, W\in D_{\bar\sigma}^{r-1}(A),\lambda\in \wedge_{\bar\sigma}^r(A)$
such that
\begin{align*}
i_X^{\bar\sigma}(\lambda)= \sum_{i=1}^r\bar
\sigma(\bar{|X|},{|\bar\lambda_1|+\cdots+|\bar\lambda_{i-1}|})
\langle X,\lambda_i \rangle
(\lambda_1\wedge_{\bar\sigma}\dots\wedge_{\bar\sigma} \hat
\lambda_i\wedge_{\bar\sigma}\dots\wedge_{\bar\sigma} \lambda_r),
\end{align*}
see \cite{h4}. Clearly, $
i_{X}^{\bar\sigma}(\lambda\wedge_{\bar\sigma}\theta)=i_{X}(\lambda)\wedge_{\bar\sigma}\theta
+\bar\sigma(|\bar X|,|\lambda|)\lambda\wedge_{\bar\sigma}i_X(\theta)
$, for $\lambda \wedge_{\bar\sigma} \theta\in
\wedge_{\bar\sigma}^r(A)$. Again, if the symmetry is
$\bar\sigma=\tau$ of (\ref{sdecomp}) this is the classical inner
derivative
%\begin{align*}$i_X(\lambda)(W)=\langle
W,i_X(\lambda)\rangle=(-1)^{|W|_\mathbb{Z}}\langle X\wedge
W,\lambda\rangle $%\end{align*}
and $ i_X(\lambda\wedge\theta)=
\langle X,\lambda \rangle \wedge \theta +
(-1)^{|\lambda|_\mathbb{Z}} \lambda\wedge \langle X,\theta \rangle
$, with $\lambda,\theta\in \wedge^r(A)$, see \cite{krasil}.

Now consider the polynomial algebra $\mathbb{C}[t,x,y,z]$ as a $\bar\sigma$-symmetric $\mathbb{Z}^{5}$-graded algebra, and also the $\bar\sigma$-symmetric $\mathbb{Z}^{5}$-graded algebras  $\wedge_{\bar\sigma}^{\cdot}(\mathbb{C}[t,x,y,z])$ and $D_{\bar\sigma}^{\cdot}(\mathbb{C}[t,x,y,z])$.

Fix the following notation on two derivations $W$ and $U$ and one 1-form $\lambda$\begin{align*}
W=w_t\partial_t+w_x\partial_x+w_y\partial_y+w_z\partial_z,\quad
U=u_t\partial_t+u_x\partial_x+u_y\partial_y+u_z\partial_z, \\
\lambda=\phi d_t+V_xd_x+V_yd_y+V_zd_z.
\end{align*}
The derivations $W$ and $U$ have a grading $|\bar W|,|\bar U|\in\mathbb{Z}^{5}$, where
%\begin{align*}$w_i\in \mathbb{C}[t,x,y,z]_{|\bar W| + 1_i}$,
$u_i\in\mathbb{C}[t,x,y,z]_{|\bar U| + 1_i}$%\end{align*}
such that
$
 w_i\partial_i\in D^1(\mathbb{C}[t,x,y,z]_{|\bar W|})
$ and $
u_i\partial_i\in D^1(\mathbb{C}[t,x,y,z]_{|\bar U|}).
$
The 1-form $\lambda$ has the grading $|\bar\lambda|=1_5$, where
$|\bar\phi|=-1_1$, $|\bar V_x|=-1_2$, $|\bar V_y|=-1_3$ and $|\bar V_z|=-1_4$.

\begin{theorem}\label{longtheorem}
The $\bar\sigma$-symmetric exterior derivative of $\lambda$ applied to two $\bar\sigma$-symmetric derivations W and U
%\begin{align*}
$d^{\bar \sigma}\lambda (W,U)=W(\lambda_U)+\bar\sigma(|\bar W|,|\bar
U|)U(\lambda_W) -\lambda_{[W,U]^{\sigma}} $
%\end{align*}
 has
the form
\begin{align*}
d^{\bar \sigma}\lambda (W,U)
=&
-\bar\sigma(1_5,|\bar W|)\cdot\\
&\cdot(
w_xV_xu_t\partial_t+w_yV_yu_t\partial_t+ w_zV_zu_t\partial_t
+w_t\phi u_x\partial_x+w_yV_yu_x\partial_x+ w_zV_zu_x\partial_x\\
&+w_t\phi u_y\partial_y+w_xV_xu_y\partial_y+ w_zV_zu_y\partial_y
+w_t\phi u_z\partial_z+ w_xV_xu_z\partial_z+w_yV_yu_z\partial_z)\\
&-\bar\sigma(|\bar W|,|\bar U|+1_5) \cdot \\
&\cdot(u_xV_xw_t\partial_t+u_yV_yw_t\partial_t+u_zV_zw_t\partial_t
+u_t\phi w_x\partial_x+u_yV_yw_x\partial_x+u_zV_zw_x\partial_x\\
&+u_t\phi w_y\partial_y+u_xV_xw_y\partial_y+u_zV_zw_y\partial_y
+u_t\phi w_z\partial_z+u_xV_xw_z  \partial_z+u_yV_yw_z\partial_z)
\end{align*}
\end{theorem}\begin{proof}
The proof is straight forward calculations of the explicit form of $d^{\bar \sigma}\lambda (W,U)$.
\end{proof}\begin{theorem}\label{longtheorem2}
The quantized $\bar\sigma_{\bar q}$-symmetric exterior derivative of a 1-form $\lambda$ applied to two $\bar\sigma_{\bar q}$-symmetric derivations $W$ and $U$ is
\begin{align*}
d_{\bar q}^{\bar\sigma_{\bar q}}\lambda (W,U)
=&
-\bar q(|\bar W|,|\bar U|)\bar\sigma_{\bar q}(1_5,|\bar W|) \cdot \\
&\cdot(
w_xV_xu_t\partial_t+w_yV_yu_t\partial_t+w_zV_zu_t\partial_t
+w_t\phi u_x\partial_x+w_yV_yu_x\partial_x+w_zV_zu_x\partial_x\\
&+w_t\phi u_y\partial_y+w_xV_xu_y\partial_y+w_zV_zu_y\partial_y
+w_t\phi u_z\partial_z+ w_xV_xu_z\partial_z+w_yV_yu_z\partial_z)\\
&-\bar q(|\bar U|,|\bar W|)\bar\sigma_{\bar q}(|\bar W|,|\bar U|+1_5) \cdot \\
&\cdot(u_xV_xw_t\partial_t
+u_yV_yw_t\partial_t
+u_zV_zw_t\partial_t
+u_t\phi w_x\partial_x
+u_yV_yw_x\partial_x
+u_zV_zw_x\partial_x\\
&+u_t\phi w_y\partial_y
+u_xV_xw_y\partial_y
+u_zV_zw_y\partial_y
+u_t\phi w_z\partial_z
+u_xV_xw_z\partial_z
+u_yV_yw_z\partial_z)
\end{align*}
\end{theorem}\begin{proof}
The proof is similar to that of theorem \ref{longtheorem}.
\end{proof}
